posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked:
I know there was a thread on this already but that was a while ago and now the season is over.

So, what cool software stuff did you add this year? Anything unique/specific to your team? Plans for next year? Stuff you tried to add but ran out of time?

posts.name: Paul Regnier
posts.cooked: we have some freshmen working on custom ML note detection that will hopefully be used this off-season, a project that they came in and asked to do completely unprompted which is cool. Besides that, we will probably just clean up our code and fix all the massive janky state machines for the offseason

We added auto orientation using our gyro to automatically face whatever way we needed for the amp / speaker. Instead of needing to manually face a direction, you could just hold down a button and the robot would turn for you while moving back from the other side of the field. We also had a button to switch between field centric and robot centric field view, which was helpful when lining up at the stage to climb. I’d love other similar ideas on what we could add to our swerve drivebase to help our drivers out for next season.

We did some simple things this year that we’ve never done in the past like intake automatically retracting after picking up a note. We also didn’t toggle the intake in or out, the driver had to hold the trigger down for the intake to deploy. It would override the trigger once a game piece was picked up.  We instituted a pulse on the intake rollers to somewhat auto center the game piece in our intake. Also when climbing the operator had to hold down the button to extend the elevator and once the button was let go of the robot would climb. Like I said pretty simple stuff but it did make a difference for us.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.custom_user_title: My views are mine and mine alone

posts.name: Aiden Keegan
posts.cooked:
We did a lot of this too, we also added a slight ‘Aim assist’ to the drivetrains translation as well as rotation while we were aligning to the amp, which helped speed up our amp cycle times quite a bit.

Another cool thing we added was both automatic note pickup and automatic note rotation. If a note was completely out of the driver’s view (i.e., pressed against the alliance wall), the operator could press a button, and it would automatically drive to and intake the note using a custom vision model running on a LL3 with a coral.  Later in the season, we added a button that rotates to the note and intakes it, but doesn’t drive, allowing for the same aim assist capability, without ever having to take control of the drivetrain away from the driver.

posts.name: Kiet Chau
posts.cooked:
We had a couple cool tools that our software & controls team cooked on this year. Major credit goes to Dustin Lieu @doostin , FRC 968 alum that’s now mentoring 1538. This guy is an absolute GOAT.

We didn’t want to pay for a ChArUco calibration board, but, had an old iPad Pro lying around. So, we made a calibrating tool that’s web based that can be used on the device resulting in a mean error of less than 0.3px!! image 2160×1620 63.4 KB

image 2160×1620 63.4 KB

image 2160×1620 63.4 KB

Made a camera intrinsics calibration tool that can be used against a phone camera

We wanted a fast and accurate way of checking the field AprilTag positions against what was provided in the manual without having the robot present. We came up with a solution that uses a phone with a really good camera (an iPhone, any modern day phone camera should do).

image 1073×1085 115 KB

image 1073×1085 115 KB

image 1073×1085 115 KB

A video would be recorded for post-processing that would include the speaker AprilTags in view. We’d “pin” one of the speaker AprilTags and use that as a reference to then calculate the relative position to all of the other tags in view. Multiple videos can be stitched together, eventually resulting in an updated field map that could be dumped into PhotonVision (we had one for Limelight, but, switched to PV mid-season)

Here’s our open sourced projects for the stuff referenced above:

Contribute to TheHolyCows/cowlibration-board development by creating an account on GitHub.

https://theholycows.github.io/cowlibration-board/application/

Contribute to TheHolyCows/cowlibration-camera development by creating an account on GitHub.

Contribute to TheHolyCows/cowlibration-field development by creating an account on GitHub.

(edit, @'d the guy)

link_counts.title: What's the coolest feature your team/or another team implemented in software this year?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CEO @ Vivid-Hosting, Mentor @ Team 1538 / The Holy Cows

posts.custom_user_title: CEO @ Vivid-Hosting, Mentor @ Team 1538 / The Holy Cows

posts.cooked:
Our team fully automated the entire scoring process for the first time this year. In previous years, our drivers had to mainly do everything on their own (including extension, lineup, pickup, etc.), but switching to all NEO’s (for the encoders), allowed us to automate most of the driver’s tasks.

We made it so that when our driver presses and holds down a button, our robot will automatically approach, lineup, extend and score and retract without our driver having to do anything. We felt that we had to do it because of some of the bad sightlines on the field from things like the stage and speaker.

We tried to fully automate the intaking process as well (near source), but without a beam-break sensor, trying to detect when a note was inserted was tricky, however making the lining up process automatic was better than having our drivers do it by hand.

posts.name: Dustin
posts.cooked:
Thanks @kiettyyyy for the comprehensive summary!

Here are samples of a calibration video and resulting field map we used in competition.

Notice that even on an official field, the observed positions of the tags don’t perfectly align with the ideal positions given in the game manual. In this case, the source tags were further outside of the field than expected. This difference could lead to inconsistent behavior where shots are less accurate when certain tags are in view of the camera, but by calibrating the tag positions on the field we can account for this.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: What benefit does a video provide over a picture of each view?

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: my personal theory is that it might help with pose ambiguity

posts.name: Alex He
posts.cooked: This is our first year of using swerve and despite the fact that we spent 4 months in the swerve and failed in java, we actually finished it (not perfect at all) in python and make it drivable. So in the offseason, we are planned to focus on the swerve drive and even add some features if time is loose before the next kickoff.

posts.name: Dustin
posts.cooked:
Amicus1:

What benefit does a video provide over a picture of each view?

There’s noise in the data, so capturing a video gives us more samples for the solver to fit a map to. If we just captured one image, we wouldn’t know if we got the “middle” of the noise or one of the extremes.

nevadexehs:

my personal theory is that it might help with pose ambiguity

Initially we recorded one continuous video to capture all the tags, but we had issues with ambiguous tag poses at certain angles when moving between tags. So instead, we hand-picked specific oblique angles that reduced the chances of ambiguous tag poses.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: I’m a little surprised your problem formulation in Ceres wasn’t able to deal with the ambiguity. You’ve got it set up as basically a Structure from Motion problem, right?

posts.name: Emil Sriram
posts.cooked: What solver is this? How can someone else do something like this?

posts.name: Dustin
posts.cooked:
thatmattguy:

I’m a little surprised your problem formulation in Ceres wasn’t able to deal with the ambiguity. You’ve got it set up as basically a Structure from Motion problem, right?

Currently it’s setup as a pose graph optimization problem that works off the relative 3D poses computed from OpenCV’s solvePnP(), so in a sense it’s “unaware” of the pose ambiguity problem. It might be better to setup the solver to minimize reprojection error instead, and have it work off each tag’s 2D image points.

EmilTheMeal:

What solver is this? How can someone else do something like this?

We’re using the Ceres Solver and we’ve open sourced everything on Github!

Contribute to TheHolyCows/cowlibration-field development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Gotcha. I suspect you’ll get (if not better, at least different) results by using tag corners directly. The factor graph stuff I’m playing with uses them, and it’s kind of awesome how at least for localization it handles changing trust with range and ambiguity for free as part of the model. I’m using gtsam, but at the end of the day it’s just a LM solver in a trench coat, so doing the same thing in ceres should be possible. Curious to hear how this changes results if you do decide trying the pixel coordinate observation formulation instead!

posts.name: Emil Sriram
posts.cooked: Are there any docs describing how to use it, and the python scripts (or can you explain it)? How do I go from a video to a new .fmap file? If it doesn’t produce an fmap file, does it return the transformation matrix for each april tag in the videos.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
This is amazing work.   I hope to get some time this summer to look into it.  hopefully it will be adaptable from year to year with minimal changes.

Do you have plans on setting up a rich guide on how to use it all together.  I only looked briefly at the repos and the instructions look light, I am sure we can eventually figure it out though.

Also unrelated.   Thanks for the workshop last December.   Our team definitely benefitted.  We had the most organized and robust electrical we ever have had.

posts.name: Dustin
posts.cooked:
EmilTheMeal:

Are there any docs describing how to use it, and the python scripts (or can you explain it)?

Bmongar:

Do you have plans on setting up a rich guide on how to use it all together.

I added more documentation to the READMEs on all three repos and also sample data to the cowlibration-field repo to test the calibration tool with! If you run into any problems running any of the calibration tools, feel free to raise a GitHub issue.

EmilTheMeal:

How do I go from a video to a new .fmap file?

Currently, the calibration tool only generates field maps in the WPILib format and does not generate .fmap files compatible with the LimeLight.
